gmx:name.gco:CharacterString: Feature catalog for Terrestrial Ecoregions: San Francisco Bay Area, California, 2011

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: ESRI

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: ESRI

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: ESRI

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: ESRI

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: This field replaces ECO_CODE, which caused confusion as it did not change when MHT changed.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: This field replaces ECO_CODE, which caused confusion as it did not change when MHT changed.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Code includes the original Realm, MHT and Ecoregion Number for each ecoregion. Replaced by ECO_ID_U as the primary key.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Code includes the original Realm, MHT and Ecoregion Number for each ecoregion. Replaced by ECO_ID_U as the primary key.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Every Ecoregion has a unique name, named by Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) , Wiken (1986) and The Nature Conservancy (2005)

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Every Ecoregion has a unique name, named by Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) , Wiken (1986) and The Nature Conservancy (2005)

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Every Ecoregion has a unique number, by Realm and MHT, based on Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) and The Nature Conservancy

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Every Ecoregion has a unique number, by Realm and MHT, based on Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) and The Nature Conservancy

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Combination of the Eco_Code and Eco_name fields
The identifier used by CLS for each ecoregion. This field will help CLS to stay current by allowing it to link to this data, which is regularly updated.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: CLS (via Jen Johnson)

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: CLS (via Jen Johnson)

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Comments on edits and changes to attributes and polygons for ecoregions.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Continental-scale biogeographic regions defined by differences in geologic and climatic history which contain distinct assemblages of plants and animals, particularly at higher taxonomic levels. The realms used are roughly based on Pielou's "biogeographic regions." (Pielou, E.C., 1979, Biogeography. Wiley, NY). The REALM item consists of a two letter code. Attributed by The Nature Conservancy (2005) for Canada and The United States, and by Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) for the rest of the Globe.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Continental-scale biogeographic regions defined by differences in geologic and climatic history which contain distinct assemblages of plants and animals, particularly at higher taxonomic levels. The realms used are roughly based on Pielou's "biogeographic regions." (Pielou, E.C., 1979, Biogeography. Wiley, NY). The REALM item consists of a two letter code. Attributed by The Nature Conservancy (2005) for Canada and The United States, and by Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) for the rest of the Globe.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Continental-scale biogeographic regions defined by differences in geologic and climatic history which contain distinct assemblages of plants and animals, particularly at higher taxonomic levels. The realms used are roughly based on Pielou's "biogeographic regions." (Pielou, E.C., 1979, Biogeography. Wiley, NY). The REALM item consists of a two letter code. Attributed by The Nature Conservancy (2005) for Canada and The United States, and by Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) for the rest of the Globe.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Continental-scale biogeographic regions defined by differences in geologic and climatic history which contain distinct assemblages of plants and animals, particularly at higher taxonomic levels. The realms used are roughly based on Pielou's "biogeographic regions." (Pielou, E.C., 1979, Biogeography. Wiley, NY). The REALM item consists of a two letter code. Attributed by The Nature Conservancy (2005) for Canada and The United States, and by Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) for the rest of the Globe.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Major Habitat Type Number as defined by World Wildlife Fund (Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein, 2002)

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Broad kinds of ecoregions that: a) Experience comparable climatic regimes; b) Have similar vegetation structure; c) Display similar spatial patterns of biodiversity; d) Contain flora and fauna with similar guild structures and life histories; e) Have similar minimum requirements and thresholds for maintaining certain biodiversity features; and f) Have similar sensitivities to human disturbance. Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) - http://worldwildlife.org/science/data/attributes.cfm

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Broad kinds of ecoregions that: a) Experience comparable climatic regimes; b) Have similar vegetation structure; c) Display similar spatial patterns of biodiversity; d) Contain flora and fauna with similar guild structures and life histories; e) Have similar minimum requirements and thresholds for maintaining certain biodiversity features; and f) Have similar sensitivities to human disturbance. Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) - http://worldwildlife.org/science/data/attributes.cfm

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Major Habitat Type Name as defined by World Wildlife Fund (Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein, 2002)

Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) - http://worldwildlife.org/science/data/attributes.cfm

Olson, D. M. and E. Dinerstein (2002) - http://worldwildlife.org/science/data/attributes.cfm

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Combination of Realm and MHT into a single field, to make analysis easier

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Ecoregional boundary update status. This describes if the ecoregional boundary is original, a draft, or updated.
